column5: review

This is the longest and most vulnerable of my reviews, but the most meaningful, so if you’d like to get to know me better, please do read it! I was set to crown Nala Sinephro’s album as the best of the year; I’d never experienced brilliance like its before. But after a trip to London a few weeks ago, I realized it had to be brat. It’s not just a great album; it’s a mirror to my life and my identity struggles. 

I was in London– ironic.  My earliest identity was as someone who challenged the British. From the start, I was force fed deep pride in resisting the Anglo oppressor—by both India and America. I was taught that life’s transience demands challenging the status quo, that revolution is always on the table. This became my identity—to be progressive, to fight, to seek the new and indie. I love it, but being that fluid left me as a “man without a country.

Being Indian in America didn’t help. People couldn’t pronounce my name. My language sounded weird. I wasn’t Christian. I couldn’t invite people to my smelly house. I looked around and saw Black and Hispanic people being celebrated for their “coolness,” and East Asians adopting white names to blend in. 9/11 surely didn’t help. Lack of TV role models? What if every TV character was a joke– not funny, a joke. I’ll never have a memory before feeling insecure. It’s always been. Not feeling like I have to prove to everyone why I’m worth being seen, or heard or even existing.

Until I was about 27, I buried my insecurity and used knowledge and comedy to make myself feel valuable. I became the guy who could make jokes about brownness that no one else could, who knew random facts and about anything to start a meaningful chat with anyone. Why pick up so many random skills? Why do I travel so much– and choose the timeless icon bar over the trendy lounge? It was all to stay connected to people meaningfully, to know their lives and history and culture intimately, to prove I was worth their attention and make them feel real joy near me. Without that, I felt like I’d just be the butt of the joke.

I was terrified of making anyone uncomfortable. I missed chances to connect—never telling the pretty girls how I felt, avoiding confrontations with bullies, lying to my family. For years, my insecurity sabotaged relationships. I pushed people away, letting my fear hurt them. Deliberately pushing them away to stop feeling like an imposter and kill the relationship. I’m so sorry. If you’re holding onto those moments, please reach out so we can talk.

Truth is, as some of you know, I was one poorly tied knot away from not making it. Had it not been for music, I probably wouldn’t have. It helped me heal by helping me feel understood then and I started making these lists in 2009 as gratitude. Music is an enigma, but it helps us connect to the world in ways words or pictures can’t. Funny though– my earliest identity was shaped by rejecting the British, who would I be without British music? The first album I remember hearing was When I Was Born for the 7th Time; The first song I thought was cool was Guns of Brixton; I learned guitar so I could play The Bends; My favorite song is This Charming Man; I was glued to TV watching the power of Geldof’s Live 8; I’ll never stop dancing thanks to Jamie XX; David Bowie was who I modeled my entire persona off of.

When I got here, London, and heard Charli everywhere—every club, every shop—it hit me. This was the people’s music: a progressive, radical, brown woman, living a mixed identity, emotional, wanting to talk about her feelings but still craving the party, wanting to make people laugh, trying to fit in yet stand out, silly, serious, confident, vulnerable, insecure—this was everything I felt but couldn’t always express. To hear it celebrated across the city, made me cry. It was them; it was her—and it was me. Charli had woven together all those pieces, just as I had, and created something that connected her to everyone. It was a beautiful reflection of how we both tried to bridge our worlds, and it resonated with people in a way that gave me the deepest sense of belonging.

Recently, I’ve realized that my pursuits—travel, hobbies, experiences—were all about one thing: connecting with others. Despite an insecure motivation, that is my identity, and I’m finally proud of being a connector. But brat showed me something even deeper: I don’t need to rid myself of my insecurity. It’s my strength. Without it, I’d live a much duller life, less driven to grow. It’ll never fully go away, and I shouldn’t want it to. I need to control it, but never wish it away, because it’s what keeps me evolving, reaching for more, and truly connecting. Thank you, Charli, it’s been a brat life.

'Endless' is an atmospheric exploration of jazz and ambient soundscapes, blending intricate harp melodies with ethereal tones. A deeply meditative and emotive experience, the album feels like a journey through dreamlike realms.
column6: Alice Coltrane; Floating Points; Brian Eno

column5: An emotional whirlwind of abstract beats and tender vocals, this album combines glitchy experimental sounds with heartfelt lyrics. It’s an exploration of vulnerability and catharsis.
Naima Bock creates an intimate yet expansive folk album, where pastoral melodies meet poignant storytelling. The subtle instrumentation draws you into her reflective world.
column6: Big Thief; Angel Olsen; Aldous Harding

column2: No More Water: Gospel of James Baldwin
column5: Meshell Ndegeocello crafts an homage to James Baldwin's legacy with a gospel-infused exploration of racial identity and resistance. A powerful, evocative album that combines her deep artistry with social critique.
This collective of female West African musicians blends vibrant Afrobeat rhythms with feminist messages of empowerment and resistance. 'Musow Danse' is a dynamic and celebratory record.
column6: Oumou Sangaré; Fela Kuti; Songhoy Blues

column5: Nilufer Yanya continues her mastery of nuanced, guitar-driven indie rock with 'My Method Actor,' an introspective yet bold collection of songs about identity and vulnerability.
Beyoncé explores themes of individuality and Americana with 'Cowboy Carter,' blending country influences with her unmistakable R&B roots. A fresh, genre-defying take on her artistry.
A vibrant celebration of Zambian nightlife, 'A Dancefloor in Ndola' merges electronic beats with traditional African rhythms, creating a dancefloor-ready experience.
column6: Black Coffee; DJ Lag; Burna Boy

column5: Justice returns with 'Hyperdrama,' a pulsating journey through high-energy beats and dramatic crescendos. A bold continuation of their iconic sound.
column6: Daft Punk; Gesaffelstein; The Chemical Brothers

column5: James Blake and Lil Yachty craft a genre-blurring record that combines ethereal production with introspective lyricism, pushing the boundaries of modern hip-hop.
column6: Frank Ocean; Tyler, the Creator; Kendrick Lamar

column2: Where We’ve Been Where We Go From Here
column5: A heartfelt exploration of past and future, Friko’s debut album offers melancholic melodies and raw, introspective lyrics.
Two Shell delivers hypnotic, bass-heavy tracks that toe the line between underground club music and experimental electronica.

column2: Oh My God - That's So Me
column5: Okay Kaya’s witty and introspective lyricism shines in 'That’s So Me,' blending dreamy pop melodies with clever, self-aware storytelling.
An enigmatic and challenging album that deconstructs rock music into surrealist soundscapes, 'Rong Weicknes' is an otherworldly listening experience.
Kinkajous crafts intricate jazz compositions that balance technical mastery with emotive storytelling. A stunning exploration of contemporary jazz.
Laura Marling returns with 'Patterns on Repeat,' a contemplative album filled with rich acoustic textures and her poetic lyricism that explores cycles of life and love.
column6: Joni Mitchell; Big Thief; Iron & Wine

column5: With 'The Jester,' Wallice combines quirky humor and heartfelt introspection, creating catchy indie pop tunes that explore the absurdities of modern life.
Sofie Royer’s 'Young-Girl Forever' is a daring exploration of pop's outer limits, blending avant-garde production with a deeply personal narrative.
'Pointy Heights' showcases Fousheé’s soulful voice and boundary-pushing songwriting, merging heartfelt ballads with experimental production.
Shugo Tokumaru’s intricate instrumentation and playful melodies in 'Song Symbiosis' offer a whimsical journey through soundscapes rich in texture and detail.
column6: Sufjan Stevens; Devendra Banhart; Animal Collective

column5: Skegss’s breezy melodies and raw energy make 'Pacific Highway Music' a standout indie rock album, perfect for sunny road trips and carefree days.
Photay’s 'Windswept' is a serene exploration of electronic and ambient music, blending natural sounds with intricate beats for a meditative experience.
'Caracoles' is a vibrant celebration of Afro-Cuban music, combining traditional rhythms with modern jazz influences in an energetic, soulful performance.
column6: Buena Vista Social Club; Ibrahim Ferrer; Chucho Valdés

column5: Tourist’s 'Memory Morning' is an emotional electronic journey, blending lush soundscapes with driving beats to evoke moments of nostalgia and introspection.
